reasoning: The critique targets one sub-argument/example (the wellbeing-theory divergence risk) within a large, many-pronged case for “eutopian fragility,” so even a successful rebuttal would only modestly weaken the overall position (centrality ~0.18). Its main move—future societies might be pluralistic/epistemically humble and self-correct—does somewhat undercut the paper’s use of this example, but the position largely claims ‘this could go wrong and be value-costly,’ not ‘future agents will systematically choose the narrowest/most catastrophic wellbeing model,’ so pointing to possible self-correction only weakly refutes what’s asserted (strength ~0.22). The critique is partly correct that adaptation/learning could reduce risk and that the essay does not explicitly model such dynamics, but it overstates the essay as assuming systematic bias toward catastrophic conceptions (correctness ~0.62). It is readable and focused, with little fluff (clarity high; low dead weight). Overall impact on the position is small (overall ~0.13).
title: Future societies may self-correct wellbeing conceptions through epistemic humility and adaptation
